text: Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy law.
text_kjv: Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy law.
text_niv: Open my eyes that I may seewonderful things in your law.
text_esv: Open my eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of your law.
text_nlt: Open my eyes to seethe wonderful truths in your instructions.
text_msg: Open my eyes so I can seewhat you show me of your miracle-wonders.
text_nasb: Open my eyes, that I may behold Wonderful things from Your law.
context: Psalm 119, the longest chapter in the Bible, is an acrostic poem celebrating the Torah, the law of God. In ancient Israel, the Torah wasn't just a set of rules; it was considered God's revealed will and wisdom, a source of life, guidance, and blessing. It encompassed the Pentateuch, the first five books of the Bible traditionally attributed to Moses: Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy. Studying and meditating on the law was a central aspect of religious life. The 'law' in this context includes not just commandments, but also testimonies, statutes, precepts, and judgments – all aspects of God's revealed character and will. The psalmist, likely a royal figure or someone close to the royal court, expresses a deep longing to understand and obey God's word. Literacy rates in ancient Israel were relatively low, making access to the written word more precious and requiring dedicated effort to learn and internalize the law. Scribes and teachers played a crucial role in interpreting and transmitting the law to the general population. The psalmist’s plea for God to open his eyes signifies a recognition that human intellect alone is insufficient to grasp the full depth and beauty of God's law. He acknowledges his need for divine illumination to truly perceive the wondrous things contained within it. This highlights the dependence of humanity on God for spiritual understanding.
meaning: Psalm 119:18, 'Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy law,' is a humble prayer for spiritual enlightenment. The psalmist isn't asking for physical sight, but for the capacity to comprehend the hidden depths and profound truths within God's law. The verb 'open' (Hebrew: *galah*) signifies to uncover, reveal, or disclose. It suggests that the wonders of God's law are already present, but veiled or obscured from the psalmist's understanding. He recognizes his own limitations, acknowledging that his natural perception is insufficient to grasp the divine wisdom embedded within the scriptures. The phrase 'wondrous things' (Hebrew: *niphla'ot*) refers to extraordinary, amazing, and miraculous aspects of God's character and plan as revealed in His law. These are not merely legalistic rules but reflections of God's glory, holiness, justice, mercy, and love. The 'law' (*torah*) isn't just a set of commandments; it's a comprehensive guide to living a life pleasing to God, revealing His nature and purposes. The prayer implies that true understanding of God's word requires more than intellectual effort; it demands a spiritual awakening and divine intervention. God must actively reveal these wonders to the seeker. This verse highlights the inherent limitations of human reason when it comes to spiritual matters. The psalmist understands that the mysteries of God are beyond human comprehension without divine aid. It emphasizes the importance of humility and dependence on God in the pursuit of spiritual knowledge. It is not enough to simply read the scriptures; we must pray for God to open our eyes to the truth they contain.
application: In today's world, bombarded with information and distractions, Psalm 119:18 remains profoundly relevant. We too often approach Scripture as just another book, failing to recognize the 'wondrous things' it holds. Practically, this verse encourages us to cultivate a posture of prayerful dependence when reading the Bible. Before opening your Bible each day, consciously ask God to 'open your eyes' to understand His word more deeply. Don't rush through the text simply to check it off a list. Instead, read slowly and deliberately, meditating on the meaning of each verse and asking God to reveal its significance for your life. Consider using different study methods like lectio divina or journaling to engage more deeply with the text. Acknowledge your own limitations. We often filter scripture through our own biases and preconceived notions. Ask God to reveal these blind spots and to give you a fresh perspective on His truth. Share your insights with others. Discuss the passages you are studying with fellow believers in a small group or Bible study. This can provide valuable insights and help you see the text in new ways. Practice obedience. True understanding of God's word is always linked to obedience. As you gain insights from Scripture, commit to putting them into practice in your daily life. This will deepen your understanding and strengthen your relationship with God. Reflect on how the 'law' or biblical principles apply to your contemporary situation. How can you apply wisdom from Proverbs to your business dealings? How can Jesus' teachings on love influence your interactions with difficult people? Look for practical applications that transform your character and conduct. Recognize that spiritual understanding is a lifelong journey, not a destination. Continuously seek God's guidance and be open to new revelations from His word. The Holy Spirit is our teacher, and he delights in illuminating the truths of Scripture for those who seek him sincerely.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you with a humble heart, acknowledging my need for your divine illumination. Open my eyes, Lord, that I may behold wondrous things out of your law. I confess that I often read your Word with a distracted mind and a hardened heart. Forgive me for not approaching Scripture with the reverence and expectation it deserves. Holy Spirit, be my guide as I delve into your Word. Remove the scales from my eyes and reveal the hidden treasures within. Help me to understand your will and to apply your truth to my life. Grant me a hunger for your Word that will drive me to seek you daily. Fill me with wisdom and discernment so that I may not be deceived by false teachings. Thank you for the gift of your Word, which is a lamp unto my feet and a light unto my path. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'behold wondrous things' implies seeing the extraordinary, amazing, and miraculous aspects of God's character and plans revealed in His law. It's not just understanding the rules, but grasping the depth of God's love, justice, and wisdom contained within them. It is the unveiling of God's glory.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to 'behold wondrous things'?

faqs.answer: The 'law' (Torah) extends beyond mere commandments; it encompasses the whole of God's revealed word, including His testimonies, statutes, precepts, and judgments. It represents His complete instruction for righteous living and reveals His character.
faqs.question: Q2: How is 'law' defined in the context of this verse?

faqs.answer: Human intellect alone is insufficient to fully grasp spiritual truth. Our minds are limited, and sin can cloud our understanding. We need divine assistance to overcome our biases and see the true meaning of God's word.
faqs.question: Q3: Why is it necessary to pray for God to open our eyes to understand the Bible?

faqs.answer: Practically, apply this by praying before reading Scripture, meditating on the text, discussing it with others, and committing to obey what you learn. Seek to integrate biblical principles into your everyday decisions and actions.
faqs.question: Q4: What are some practical ways to apply this verse in my daily life?

faqs.answer: This verse highlights our dependence on the Holy Spirit as our teacher and guide. The Spirit illuminates the truths of Scripture, revealing the 'wondrous things' to those who seek God with a sincere heart, enabling true comprehension.
faqs.question: Q5: How does this verse relate to the role of the Holy Spirit in understanding Scripture?
